title: How to get 10000 YouTube subscribers - Quora

response.answer_text: Consider your YouTube channel as your baby that your have to feed and nurture. It will take at least 2–3 years before you see positive results. Now, do the following. Although i cannot guarantee your success, but there is a good chance that you could be successful if you do the following things: Create interesting/informative/creative videos. Without good content i.e content people love, you will get nowhere. Take your time making a video. A single video per year with a million views is much better than daily videos which gain less than 100 views.Find out a niche which you love and focus ONLY on that niche. Do not create a channel of a niche that you don’t love, otherwise you will feel bored to make videos because creating and nurturing a channel takes serious time.Give a good video title so that people can search for your content and find it. Also give a good video description as well as a captivating thumbnail.Try to upload at the same time always i.e upload consistently.Never ever, EVER buy views,subscribers or even do sub4sub. Your channel may or may not get banned but it’s no use other than waste of time, trust me.Use good quality microphone i.e your voice should be audible. In the beginning, you can get away with only your mobile, but as time passes, invest in a camera and microphone.Do not make shaky videos. People will have dizziness while watching the videos. If you can afford to buy a gimbal, buy one. Else, try not to shake your videos much.Shoot your videos from different angles. Learn how to make a good video by taking different angle shots from YouTube tutorials.Instead of just uploading a video with some music, APPEAR in your videos and say something. It’s very important to keep a personal touch with your viewers.These are all i could think of right now. Feel free to contact me if you need any more advice. BTW, i gained 1000 subs and 4000 watch hours in around 11 months of creation of my channel. Hello, I am Abhinash and I have just started out as a YouTuber. Search for “THE INDIAN NOMAD” in YouTube. It’s a channel dedicated to Budget Travel, Currency and Visa. You can also get my channel’s link in my Bio and Credential. In case you find my videos entertaining or informative, do show your support by SUBSCRIBING to my channel. Thanks in advance!

1. Ask your viewers to subscribe I told you we’re starting with the easiest ones first. Sometimes your audience just needs to be reminded. The big red subscribe button is omnipresent, but you might also want to point out the bell beside it that turns on notifications for your new videos. Simple. Does this tip seem too salesy to you? This is your reminder that you’ve got valuable content, and you’re just making it easier for them to keep up with the work you do. If you’re already doing this, remember to demonstrate why your channel is worth subscribing to. And make sure you do it right when they love you the most (e.g., right after you’ve provided new and useful information, or you’ve made them laugh). Don’t do it too much, or you’ll risk turning people off. 2. End your videos by mentioning the one you’re working on next Subscribing to a YouTube channel is an act of anticipation. Viewers who’ve just seen what your brand is about are primed to want more, if you’ve done your job right. Hyping your next video, and making it clear why it’s not to be missed, is the most organic way to encourage people to tap subscribe. Of course, this requires having a good handle on your content schedule, and knowing what’s coming next. (More on that soon.) 3. Interact with your audience and make friends If you form relationships with your viewers, they’re more likely to want to keep watching your work. Respond to comments. Follow their channels back. Yes, it’s exciting if a famous YouTuber comments on your video, but who knows who’ll be famous next year. Form a community of peers and promote each other. (Yes, I’m talking about shine theory.) Also, once you’re plugged in, your audience will provide you with plenty of free content ideas for your next video. Don’t worry, you don’t have to take all of them. Manage your YouTube presence using Hootsuite and not only can you upload and schedule videos, you can also add comment streams to your dashboard. That makes it easy to review, reply, and/or moderate comments on all your videos from one place. 4. Update your channel art Your YouTube banner welcomes everyone who clicks over to check out your channel. Maybe they just watched a video and are looking for more. Maybe they’re a potential subscriber. Put your best foot forward. Your banner needs to be clean, on-brand, compelling, and—this is the fussy part—optimized for all devices. You don’t want important details covered up by your social media buttons, for instance. We have a handy guide for creating your own YouTube channel art, along with free templates with the most up-to-date dimensions. 5. Brand your thumbnails A thumbnail is a 1280 x 720px still image that acts as a cover for your video. And they are also your first, best chance to persuade people to click on your video. (Aside from your video titles, that is, but more on that later.) While some might advocate using the most “eye-catching” design (which seems to mean screaming red capslock over a man’s shocked face and a picture of a… tomato?), one size does not fit all on YouTube. But we aren’t here to earn cold views. To convert a viewer into a subscriber, take a look at your videos page. What does a new viewer see? Sleek, professional and consistent videos that imply an ongoing commitment to quality? Or a random mish-mash competing for attention? You want to aim for consistent branding in all your thumbnails. Use the same font, the same colour palette, or even the same frame composition so people know (at least subconsciously) that they’re looking at a video from your channel. For instance, John Plant has built his survivalist Primitive Technology channel up to 9.9 million subscribers with understated, minimalist thumbnails. They’re not loud, but they are consistent. And most importantly, they’re clickable.  6. Embed your videos on your website or blog This one is win-win, because embedding video on your website may well help your site’s search rankings with the Google algorithm. And as far as YouTube subscribers go, you’re presenting your video right where the people most likely to care about it are already looking. 7. Use YouTube’s clickable tools in your videos YouTube killed annotations a few years back, and good riddance. Pop-ups are one 90s throwback we’re all better off without. That said, YouTube has some other, less annoying, tools for you to use: End screens: these are still images at the end of your video where you can remind people to subscribe, or insert another call to action, before YouTube’s algorithm moves them on to the next video.Branding watermarks: this is an extra subscribe button that will hover over your video throughout, even in full screen. Like so:8. Think in terms of playlists Playlists are a great way to increase your channel’s watch time. They also motivate people to click subscribe by lining up your best content in one place. (Or your related content, in several places.) Epicurious, for instance, treats their YouTube playlists like TV series. It’s very bingeable and if, at the end, people want to be notified when there are new videos, they will subscribe.  Meanwhile, LEGO uses playlists more loosely, adding videos to relevant playlists by topic (i.e., all the Minecraft-inspired videos go in one; all the Star Wars videos in another.)  9. Run a contest If you want a short-term bump in engagement, or just feel like you’ve been languishing in a subscriber count plateau, check out our guide to running a YouTube contest. Key steps include choosing a prize that matters to your audience, and asking viewers to subscribe and turn on notifications in order to participate. 10. Celebrate your subscriber milestones Everyone loves a round number. Celebrate them and thank the people who got you there. For inspiration, here is a video with reactions for every single milestone you could possibly ever hit. Bonus: Download a free guide that reveals the exact steps one creator took to gain more than 23,000,000 views on YouTube with no budget and no expensive gear.  11. Release videos on a consistent schedule Many experts confidently cite a rule-of-thumb as to how often creators should post video to their channels. For instance: one video a week to start, increasing to 3-4 week as your channel grows. The theory is that more videos = more watch time from viewers. But prioritizing quantity over quality has drawbacks. If your goal is to convert viewers to subscribers, you need to focus on quality first, and consistency next. (Then you can start worrying about quantity.) If you upload videos consistently, then people know that more good content is coming, and they’re more likely to tap subscribe. You can also use a social media management platform like Hootsuite to schedule your videos on YouTube for publishing later. 12. Entice your audience over from other social media channels This means cross-promoting on Twitter, Instagram, Pinterest, Facebook—wherever you have a community of fans established. This can be as simple as encouraging people to check out your YouTube channel in your Instagram or Twitter bio. Please consider subscribing to my channel also All In one dose

How can I have 1k subscribers on YouTube? it’s not hard to have 1k subscribers on YouTube. if you are looking for some ways to grow subscribers, please do follow. If you have enough money, you could directly use Google adwords to place video ad for your channel for more subscribers quickly.But first please try to introspect and think why you actually subscribe to others channels.Continue to post unique and attractive video content, and set target to compete top videos on the search rank.Try to search the similar videos on YouTube, view the top videos. keep in mind the comments of these videos, know what they want, and you will know what you’ll have to generate.Do SEO for your uploaded videos on YouTube, improve the video titles(includes the main popular keywords), description(writing a brief paragraph (100-300 words) to describe the content in the video), tags(research the keywords about the video topic, then input them as the video tags), etc. and please note, Title, tags and description should be relevant.Make your video looks like the better and more professional(add subtitle on video, add video intro before the video(text which quickly intro your video), add video outro at the end of the video(ask viewers to share your video, subscribe to your channel, leave a comment, etc), you could use YouTube Movie Maker to edit videos for YouTube.Make Unique thumbnail for your videos(A very attractive thumbnail can help entice potential viewers to click on your video.)Make a playlist for your videos (If it is in the same category).be consistency in uploading videos.build a website for your YouTube channel.Create a channel trailer.Do comment related your niche videos.reply comments as more as possible so that your viewers could understand that you are loyal to them.Share your channel and videos with family and friends.

I’m telling you now, nothing comes easy with YouTube nowadays. But can you possibly reach 1000 Subscribers? DEFINITELY. Here are a few tips I can share with you to get more Subscribers on your channel. Make your channel look professional - The way your channel looks can make or break the success of your video, so be sure it adds to the allure! Create a catchy channel name and add channel art to get things started. Add a short description to your channel to give viewers a glimpse of the kind of content you’re offering.2. Always add Tags on your videos - This part is important. Without the right tags, no one’s going to find your videos. When you upload a video to your channel, choose tags that are descriptive and specific. You don’t want to use the exact same tags as everyone else, because your video will get buried that way. 3. Offer something to your viewers - If you look through the most popular YouTube videos, you’ll see that each one offers something interesting. Some offer amazing music, others offer thoughtful advice, and still others offer a few minutes of hilarious entertainment. What are you going to offer to people watching your video? Keep this in mind with every video you make. Keep in mind that this is just a jumpstart for your YouTube goal. Just be consistent and keep your drive high to achieve your goals. You can learn more about this from reading this blog that I found on the internet. Good luck!

There are several ways to get more traffic and subscribers on your YouTube channel: Good content: High quality content is one of the keys. Post engaging videos with nice graphics thumbnail. Connect with like-minded people. You can also make Facebook page and connect your YouTube channel. Join Pinterest boards.Promote in forums: Join Reddit and promote on relevant subreddits. Don’t spam or else, you will be kicked out.Optimize SEO. Improve your SEO to rank up your videos on the results page.Engagement. Engage with your subscribers by liking their comments and replying them back.Cross-collaborations. You can collaborate with brands and influencers.
